text:
<!everyone> hey folks! our 2022 salary report is live → _*<https://superpath.co/blog/content-marketing-salary-report>*_
---
*a few things:*
• would you mind helping me share this? tweets/RTs/linkedin posts would be greatly appreciated. (quickie → <https://twitter.com/jimmy_daly/status/1480938666100854786|you can RT this>)
• have questions about anything? leave them in this thread. i'll do my very best to answer them.
• huge thanks to <@U01PQFQBGHJ> and Clearscope for sponsoring this year's report. Clearscope has been a strong supporter of Superpath for a while now. check them out if you need a great tool for keyword research and/or content optimization → <https://www.clearscope.io/>
*and a few highlights/lowlights from the data:*
• average content marketer's income is $93,725 (median is $83,750)
• full-time content marketers make $91,502 vs $105,787 for freelancers
• 32% of content marketers with a job also freelance
• experience and job titles definitely translate to more income (see attached images)
• gender and racial pay gaps got worse. men made $14,604 more per year than women and white content marketers made $22,059 more than their BIPOC peers. 
all of this is broken out in more detail in the report. thanks so much to everyone who contributed!

text: I'm curious about how freelance income was reported: total revenue, take home pay after taxes?

elements.text: I'm curious about how freelance income was reported: total revenue, take home pay after taxes?

text: <@U019UEW7AQ2> the question was phrased this way: "How much pre-tax money will you make from content marketing in 2021? Please include income from all sources (employers, freelance, side gigs, etc.)."

elements.text: the question was phrased this way: "How much pre-tax money will you make from content marketing in 2021? Please include income from all sources (employers, freelance, side gigs, etc.)."

text: Shared! Thank you so much for this incredible resource, and for putting numbers up against the pay inequality we're currently seeing in the industry. Companies need to wake up and start paying ALL of their people fairly.

text:
Thanks for putting this together <@UJG9WTEKG> and for the contribution from the community! Together, we can help each other get that :bread: .

In future surveys, it might be interesting to ask if that person negotiated that salary. I heard a statistic that only 30% of people negotiate their salary, which means the other 70% are leaving so much money on the table!

elements.text: Thanks for putting this together
and for the contribution from the community! Together, we can help each other get that

.

In future surveys, it might be interesting to ask if that person negotiated that salary. I heard a statistic that only 30% of people negotiate their salary, which means the other 70% are leaving so much money on the table!

text: ^Love the idea of negotiation question. I'd love to know where people started and ended, even if you just do a table of all the negotiation numbers. I think even people that negotiate don't ask for enough in my experience. I think more salary negotiation advice at the end would make this even stronger, as well.

elements.text: ^Love the idea of negotiation question. I'd love to know where people started and ended, even if you just do a table of all the negotiation numbers. I think even people that negotiate don't ask for enough in my experience. I think more salary negotiation advice at the end would make this even stronger, as well.

text: Question about the pay gap info — is that comparing job title to job title or just gender to gender overall?

elements.text: Question about the pay gap info — is that comparing job title to job title or just gender to gender overall?

text: <@U024K88ECFN> that's gender to gender overall. so, it is possible that the cohort of women could have been less experienced than the cohort of men, which could skew the data. i think i could pull gender and experience level to level that out

text: This is fascinating. I'd be super-interested to see a global breakdown, though perhaps you don't have enough respondents to make that statistically meaningful. But folks outside the US typically get paid less, and that might be dragging down some of the data. (He says, speculating wildly).

elements.text: This is fascinating. I'd be super-interested to see a global breakdown, though perhaps you don't have enough respondents to make that statistically meaningful. But folks outside the US typically get paid less, and that might be dragging down some of the data. (He says, speculating wildly).

text: Loved the breakdown. What I would've loved to see was what the split of income was for that 32% of folks that work full time _and_ freelance.
